Posts.Content: Hi fifi, can I just add that if you are having chemo I wouldn't just go with one persons experience of chemotherapy, everybody reacts differently to, not only chemotherapy but the other treatments you may need, the chemo club here is a minefield of advice, lots of tips on there, also you have got George and Helen here who are really helpful, there is also chloecat who cruises through here, she is taking an alternative route with her treatment, and is doing well, all the other ladies on here can help with advice, it's a good gang, been a lifesaver for me x

Posts.Title: Got to have them both removed....

Posts.Content: Have you still got a drain in powderpuff?  I had terrible pain with the drain, apparently it was pressing on a nerve, I only took paracetamol with ibuprofen as codeine doesn't agree with me, it went when the drain came out, I can't remember much about that time now, I think I switched off, my brain seems to do this in times of despair xx
Posts.Title: Sickness and pain, advice needed.

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, as you will all know the constant appointments start to become very tiring after a while, however this week I've been catching up on things I couldn't do during chemo so,last week I had a 'pamper' week, I got my eyebrows threaded and tinted, my hair cut and blowdryed, my feet done at the chiropodist and today the dentist for a clean and polish, and the best of all, it's all money I have saved through packing in smoking x

Posts.Title: Had my first chemo today

Posts.Title: Nice appointments!

Posts.Content: Morning mona Lisa, I to had a grade 2 idc,  I had a mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy, when the pathology reports came back 3 tumours had been found in the breast so mastectomy was definitely the right choice for me  (only 1 showed up on mammogram )            1 out of 5 lymph nodes was infected so I was scheduled for a full clearance in September, this is where things went wrong, my original surgeon had an accident so was unable to do the op, I was transferred to a different hospital and surgery went ahead. Two weeks later I went back for the pathology reports, he hadn't removed any! He had removed a pad of fat which didn't contain any lymph nodes so the entire operation was a waste of time.  I've just finished radiotherapy to my chest and axilla area, I must admit, I wish I'd opted for  this in the first place.  Regarding chemo, I didn't have a choice as I am herceptin positive.  The choice really depends, for you, on the size and grade of tumour, plus your herceptin status x

Posts.Content: Hi weeble, I was told to try and avoid cuts, scratches and bites but it's virtually impossible, I was told if I had any of the above to keep it clean and put antiseptic on ,any sign of infection then it's off to the docs x
Posts.Title: Cuts and scratches

Posts.Content: MMorning ladies and gents, has anyone had any pain over a year at mastectomy site.  Mine is below my scar, located were bra would sit, thought it could be my bra as I've put a bit of weight on, so I left it off for a couple of days so I know it's not that.  The only way I can describe it is sore to the touch, as if I've had a cheese grater along my skin, as if it's super sensitive, there's no rash, no lumps, the odd shooting pain as if nerves are knitting, just very sensitive and sore. X
Posts.Title: Pain a while after op

Posts.Content: Evening everyone, hope you are all as well as can be expected, due to a failed axillary node clearance  (the surgeon operated, when the pathology reports came back he had failed to get any ) I ended up having to have rads to my axillary nodes, my radiotherapy finished in march however the entire area, mastectomy area and under my arm seems to becoming very stiff, is this normal?

Posts.Title: radiation to axillary

Posts.Content: Lol Helen, yes I suggested specsavers xx
Posts.Title: radiation to axillary

Posts.Content: Hi kerry, I used the cold cap during chemotherapy and kept about 70% of my hair.  It's a little uncomfortable and adds time to your treatment but overall I'm glad I used it. After your first chemotherapy it will fall out which is a little alarming but the shedding of hair did slow down, I lost some hair on the top but my cap didn't fit very well, so if you try it make sure it's on tight, and I've since heard off some of the ladies on here to put conditioner on your hair before the cap is fitted. Hope this helps kerry, good luck with your treatment x
Posts.Title: Feedback on cold cap please?

Posts.Content: Hi kerry, I had shoulder length hair, not very thick but quite a lot of it, if that makes sense, I did get it cut on the advice of my breast care nurses, not to short but a couple of inches off. When it started to come out after first chemo, it sort of frightened me and I thought should I shave it all off, but my friend advised me to wait and see if it slowed down and sure enough it did.  I know the cold cap isn't for everyone, but I'm glad I persevered, and now it's more or less back to how it was and I only finished chemotherapy in January, it's in bad condition but it's shoulder length and where it fell out is about 2 inches long xx
Posts.Title: Feedback on cold cap please?

Posts.Content: Hi kerry, I had shoulder length hair, not very thick but quite a lot of it, if that makes sense, I did get it cut on the advice of my breast care nurses, not to short but a couple of inches off. When it started to come out after first chemo, it sort of frightened me and I thought should I shave it all off, but my friend advised me to wait and see if it slowed down and sure enough it did.  I know the cold cap isn't for everyone, but I'm glad I persevered, and now it's more or less back to how it was and I only finished chemotherapy in January, it's in bad condition but it's shoulder length and where it fell out is about 2 inches long xx

Posts.Title: antidepressants

Posts.Content: Hi, hope everyone is as well as can be expected,  I was diagnosed last June with idc, mastectomy in July, chemo oct-jan, rads Feb --March now on tamoxifen and herceptin, when I was first diagnosed I was very anxious as I'm sure you all were,  I went to see my GP and asked her for antidepressants, she didn't exactly refuse, however,  she advised against them and I took her advice, however nearly one year on and I still feel extremely anxious, especially on an evening,  I'm not to bad when I'm busy during the day,iI don't relish the idea of feeling like this forever, does this feeling ever pass, would antidepressants make me feel less anxious?
Posts.Title: antidepressants

Posts.Title: antidepressants

Posts.Content: Good luck to you and your dad sister snail, it's awful when you're parents get older, mine have both gone now, I think of them everyday, they were wonderful parents as I'm sure yours are, hopefully your dad's illness can be kept under control for years to come, in the meantime make everyday count xx
Posts.Title: Confused daughter

Posts.Content: Hi syers, I'm not triple negative, I was diagnosed last June with invasive ductal bc with 1 lymph node involved, had mastectomy first then ec chemo, finished in jan, then rads in feb/March, I was grade 2,  I asked my oncologist about her decision to treat me with ec as opposed to fec and tax, her reply was based on experience of treating early stage bc, in her opinion ec would be  sufficient and slightly less harsh than fec and tax. She was certainly correct about the latter, I escaped extremely lightly with side effects, only tiredness, I'm now on 6 months of herceptin, hope you are as lucky with your treatment, chin up, it's a long road, many tears are shed, many anxious moments and feelings of utter despair, but you will get there xx
Posts.Title: EC vs FEC

Posts.Content: Of this, I have no doubt x
Posts.Title: Confused daughter

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, I think it's very difficult to stay positive all of the time, I know I can't, your symptoms could be down to the medication, however I would always get a check up, regarding low mood Denise I think most of us suffer this, I hope it gets easier with time, plus I agree with all the other posts on here, that when you here very sad news like Rio ferdinands wife ,it does bring home how unpredictable and life threatening this disease is. Helen made a good point, no one knows how long they have, I think people who are diagnosed with a serious illness get a glimpse of this and of course it has an effect, your not alone Denise xx

Posts.Content: Watch his programmes all the time judith, he's the bees knees x

Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Here,here clogheen xx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Sounds scrumptious clogheen, I'm putting the kettle on and hitting the biscuit barrell xx
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi vickster, I had treatment last year, chemo finished this January followed by radiotherapy, herceptin and tamoxifen, I'm still not back at work and don't feel emotionally well enough.  Before my diagnosis I was an absolute workaholic and led a very busy and sometimes quite stressful life.  My life has changed considerably in the last year, I hasten to add mostly for the better, I avoid stress as much as possible, I exercise more, I stopped smoking and if I'd had a crystal ball I would have done all this a lot sooner but such is life.  Give yourself time to heal in both mind and body, don't be rushed xx
Posts.Title: When will I feel better?

Posts.Content: Hi weeble, yes he gave me tablets and he told me it was something to do with the inner ear, I'm only on herceptin and tamoxifen now, I have had it before about 4 years ago so I know logically it's probably vertigo but I'm bloody paranoid now after bc x
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Julia, I know what you mean, every time I have an ache or a pain I think the worst, I've always had a bit of a phobia about dying to be honest since I was young, so obviously when I was diagnosed with bc last year it got worse, and thanks for the reply monika, I haven't got the buzzing in my ears, I think it could be what Julia had, positional, because it's worse lying down and when I do any sudden movements x
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Hi was just wondering if anyone has had vertigo post treatment, I've got it, went to a walk in doctors on Tuesday as mine couldn't fit me in for a week, and he diagnosed me, however my mind is going into overdrive at the moment and coming up with the scary possibilities that it's cancer spreading, I try not to think these things but I'm finding it so difficult x
Posts.Title: Vertigo after treatment

Posts.Content: Afternoon ladies, I finished chemotherapy in January, I used Holland and Barretts Doctor Organics olive oil cuticle softener, it's in a small green tube, it's about  £7 but lasts forever and my nails look great x

Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: My prayers are with you and your family tonight Mrs d x
Posts.Title: Good news and bad.!!

Posts.Content: Hi ladies and gentlemen, hope you are all as well as can be expected.  I really struggled with the above, both during treatment and beyond. I can't explain how it felt, fuzzy headedness, memory problems, couldn't concentrate, it was, for me, the worst side effect from all of my treatments, I'm happy to say that only in the last fortnight, it's lifted, but if there are any sceptical doctors out there who think it doesn't exist, trust me it does.  Anybody else out there had problems, I was seriously worried at one stage thinking it was permanent.
Posts.Title: Chemo fog

Posts.Content: Agree with you 100% George x
Posts.Title: Chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hi sam, welcome to the forum that no one wants to join.  Sorry about your diagnosis, so young as well, I also had grade 2, my treatment is all over now apart from tamoxifen.  I well remember those first few weeks when first diagnosed and like you wanted to switch my brain off, it does get better sam and there are plenty on here who will give you good, sound advice or even just a shoulder to cry on, always remember you're never alone.  The surgeon will remove a few lymph nodes and check to see if there are any cancer cells in them, don't be afraid if there are, there are plenty of ladies on here who had positive nodes.  Once you get your pathology reports a treatment plan will be put in place, it really all depends on your report what that plan involves. Good luck, try and get some rest and eat regularly, keep hydrated and try and get out in the autumn sunshine for some vitamin D. The above tips should help with the anxiety you will inevitably be feeling, I wish I'd took my own advice I was a bloody train crash x
Posts.Title: New to here

Posts.Content: Lol alli, it's a flippin nightmare, I've tried all sorts of products nothing helps, I'm thinking of sleeping in a hair net, I'll look ena sharples, good job I'm single x
Posts.Title: Does anyone have curly chemo hair ?

Posts.Content: Just read the link george, thanks x
Posts.Title: Chemo fog

Posts.Content: Always nice to hear good news on this site, well done, I'm also on herceptin so nice to hear xx
Posts.Title: Picking up the pieces

Posts.Content: I've just read your posts ladies and I can't believe how many young women are getting breast cancer, it is truly awful ,good luck with your treatment xx
Posts.Title: OVARY REMOVAL ER+ BC

Posts.Content: Hi  radwoman, I to was diagnosed last June, stage 2,herceptin positive and estrogen positive, so we sound as though we are at the same stage of treatment. I have, and still am, to a certain extent feeling a little bit like yourself, when I feel anxious I go walking or try to keep relatively busy, it's difficult also to make the transition from working to not working, I've just signed up with mcmillans for a 'hope' course, it lasts six weeks and covers basically everything from not sleeping  (llike you, I'm not sleeping well) to coping with fears and anxiousness, I've discussed with my GP the merits of antidepressants however she seems reluctant to prescribe them xx
Posts.Title: Emotions in turmoil when I should be getting stronger

Posts.Content: Yaaayyyýy alli owl, bet I'm crying in my beer tomorrow night lol xx
Posts.Title: enjoy bank holiday ♡♡·

Posts.Content: I have heard of this trial wearymum, I hope everything goes well for you x
Posts.Title: New Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: Morning alli, hope you are well, I've been struck down with a terrible rash on both arms, my GP thinks it's the herceptin x
Posts.Title: enjoy bank holiday ♡♡·

Posts.Content: I'm on my 5th weeble, I'm covered on both arms from elbow to wrist, got some cream off GP and it's calming down now x
Posts.Title: enjoy bank holiday ♡♡·

Posts.Content: I know, I was a bit surprised with it being my 5th one,  that was my GP though, could be anything really, but she thinks it's an allergy to herceptin, hope they don't stop it, anyway I'm getting geared up for the footy tomorrow, we are at Wembley tomorrow, not going, but going to the pub to watch it, the whole town is going I think, should be a good day as long as there's no trouble x
Posts.Title: enjoy bank holiday ♡♡·

Posts.Content: Nice to here of survivors lorylinge, I've met quite a few myself lately, I was diagnosed last June, on the mend now after chemotherapy, had the full lot, kitchen sink thrown at it x
Posts.Title: Lady in my gym

Posts.Content: Hi leen,  I was exactly the same as you,  grade 2,  I thought as well that I would avoid chemo until path reports came back with herceptin results,  I decided to have chemotherapy, I was speaking to two ladies in the chemotherapy day unit, they both had breast cancer before herceptin was available and both were herceptin positive, they were both back reoccurrence, however neither had chemotherapy the first time, nor herceptin and the reoccurrence happened 15 years down the line, it's a tough decision, one, only you can make, personally I think  for me my decision was right for me  x
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Well done Sarah, onwards and upwards now ! And kateandbiz, well done nearly there, don't be surprised if you feel down when it's over, I did and still do at times, during treatment it's a whirlwind and then suddenly you have plenty of 'thinking time ', but hey ladies you did it, CONGRATULATIONS ×
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Hey alli I'm on the moving forward course in September as well, still no mammogram results! !x
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Yes I agree Ali there certainly is x
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Yes you are indeed Ali owl, and what a bloody shame 24 years old, one thing about this s##t disease it doesn't discriminate between age, race or gender it's everybody's war xx
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Can you let me know where I can them, how much and where you stick them lol xx
Posts.Title: LadyCare Menopause Magnets

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, I'll give them a try  x
Posts.Title: LadyCare Menopause Magnets

Posts.Content: I know alli, I know it sounds daft but I'm to scared to phone them, and I wish I could of got on that course sooner but it was the first one available, when you off to Portugal? X
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: I bet you can't ,never been to Portugal but I've heard good reports, you will be ready for a break now Ali, I didn't realise how tired I would feel for such a long time after treatment and your a couple of months behind me so you must still be feeling it x
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: And on that note Ali, I'm pouring myself a vodka, putting the theme tune from rocky on, and I'm gonna sing into my hairbrush x
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Hi carole, I've finished my treatment now, I had the lot, mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, herceptin and now tamoxifen, it does go very quickly you will be pleased to know, but in the meantime plenty of water, eat as regularly as possible, I found walking a good stress buster, it also helps with fatigue and low mood, I've just recently taken up adult colouring books, they are relaxing and a good diversion x
Posts.Title: Fear & Low Moods

Posts.Content: Well done butterfly, I'm out walking for an hour every day now, small steps as they say. ......x
Posts.Title: gym

Posts.Content: I would have loved to have gone to this flowers but unfortunately I'm in sunny Morecambe that very weekend on a cheap and nasty caravan holiday out of the daily newspaper lol, regarding your check up, I know how you feel, I've got my first one looming next week and I'm bricking it, good luck flowers, best foot forward x as for your mam,  I find older people have that stoicism that sometimes eludes younger people, no disrespect to anyone, but they are tough, my mother was, and my father, they were both wonderful parents, how I could do with them now!  I hope you all have a lovely evening, especially your mum xx
Posts.Title: Deep Breaths - Here Goes...... UPDATE .......Tickets Reduced In Price...

Posts.Content: I think I'll try that, thanks for the tip, I finished chemo in January, wore the cold cap so kept most of my hair, however like yours it's thin, I'm on tamoxifen also x
Posts.Title: HAIR AFTER CHEMO !!

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny, so nice to see the young ones making their holy communion, I still remember mine and my lovely dress that mam and dad got me, well done Jenny, glad you're on the mend xx
Posts.Title: Having a lovely weekend

Posts.Content: Ctrigg your not alone, I've been the same lately, I'm off to the docs soon to discuss my lack of sleep, I think if your not sleepING everything looks bleaker than it actually is, chin up x
Posts.Title: Today has been a blurrrr

Posts.Content: Hi alli owl, it maybe because of the risk of infection still after the chemo, it stays in your body for some time, I had surgery first then chemo, also they are probably  waiting for your body to recover a little and gather strength,  failing all of the above ,maybe they are on holiday for easter xx
Posts.Title: surgery date

Posts.Content: Sorry meant drying up x
Posts.Title: Pain down side of ribs

Posts.Content: Hi penny, I've just read your post, I had a right side mastectomy last July and had the same problem, exactly the same, a line running from under the mastectomy line down to my ribs, my bc nurse said it was a lymph node dying up from when I'd had my sentinel node byopsy x
Posts.Title: Pain down side of ribs

Posts.Content: Hi hawkster, sorry to hear your news, I had a mastectomy last July due to invasive ductal bc, when they did the pathology on the breast it was multi focal so mastectomy was the right choice for me, I followed with chemo, rads,herceptin and tamoxifen, it's a long haul but goes quickly, you may dodge the chemo bullet all depends on your herceptin status and lymph nodes which you will find out a couple of weeks after surgery x
Posts.Title: It's confirmed.....cancer

Posts.Content: Oh SuMe,  how awful, I know how nerve wracking it is on your first visit, I think the problem is in these units that they are used to dealing with cancer patients day in and day out and they forget sometimes that the individual who has cancer is extremely anxious, once you start treatment you usually have the same chemotherapy nurse every time and she will be able to answer all your questions, don't be frightened to ask ANYTHING, tell her your fears and don't be afraid to cry, I did on my first session, however it does get better and once in the actual unit you will be surprised how many patients talk to you, my jaw ached with talking and laughing,  good luck, chin up you'll get there x
Posts.Title: Feeling stressed

Posts.Content: Hi m65, I am also in the same boat as you, finished chemotherapy in January and I'm off on holiday in November, try booking a travel appointment at your GP surgery, it's what I do every year, that was before chemo, so I'm certainly going to do so this year x
Posts.Title: Life after chemo - immunisations/vaccinations

Posts.Content: Sorry meant TK MAXX,  My finger slipped x
Posts.Title: Adult colouring books

Posts.Content: To maxx have them Diane, I've started doing this a couple of months ago, used to read a lot before I was diagnosed, can't concentrate enough yet to resume x
Posts.Title: Adult colouring books

Posts.Content: Hi kipper, I also am on tamoxifen and have also suffered a period of low mood, however, I'm not sure if it's the tamoxifen or just a reaction to all that's happened in the past year, I had a mastectomy last July, chemo the radiotherapy which finished in march, I'm not on antidepressants, my doctor advised against them, so it's very difficult to pinpoint the cause, but when you think our minds and bodies go through an awful lot in the space of a year I would think it's quite normal to feel this way. Regarding tamoxifen, I think it's up to the individual, I, personally am going to persevere with it, if it helps to prevent a reoccurrence then it's worth it x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: Denise, you look great, love the hair xx
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Good news pat, hopefully you will feel a lot better for it, I think I had it relatively easy om my EC chemotherapy xx

Posts.Content: Well done dragonlady, we must have been neck to neck with treatment, I was diagnosed June last year x
Posts.Title: 1st Mammogram

Posts.Content: I am thanks dragonlady, I'm still on herceptin, and tamoxifen, not liking the tamoxifen, I was diagnosed the 26th of June, hope you are doing ok as well x
Posts.Title: 1st Mammogram

Posts.Content: onwards and upwards for you now, well done, I will always compare chemo to the 'grand national ' many hurdles, but crossing the finishing line is CLASS x
Posts.Title: Final chemo done.... woohoo!!

Posts.Content: Well done mo you're nearly there, sod the housework xx
Posts.Title: Tax reduction

Posts.Content: Hi mo, try and get to your look good feel better appointment it's brilliant and relaxing, and the goody bag is the bees knees, however I was on chemo when I went so felt awful, some of the other ladies on it were a year out of treatment so in hindsight maybe I should of waited but the appointments are like goldust, shows how many have got this awful disease xx
Posts.Title: Tax reduction

Posts.Content: Yeah I agree mo, no good if you feel lousy, you won't enjoy it, may as well save it as a treat for when your over all this awful treatment, chin up mo, you will get there xx
Posts.Title: Tax reduction

Posts.Content: Well said grannylara, rads are a walk in the park compared to chemo, not long now grannylara ,another hurdle over, congratulations x
Posts.Title: Finally started radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Lol nettie, not downhill, where I live going downhill means your on your last legs x
Posts.Title: Finally started radiotherapy

Posts.Content: This is going to be a tissue job ladies and gents, 9 0 clock BBC 1 , so sad, makes you realise how fragile life is, it can change in a heartbeat x

Posts.Content: Lol x
Posts.Title: Song for Jenny

Posts.Content: Me 2 Ali, I've got chocolate and tissues, no alcohol tonite though I've had the hangover from hell today, so I've been on a downer Ali, this show will probably tip me over the edge x
Posts.Title: Song for Jenny

Posts.Content: Ok I'll give it a go Ali, tried everything, here we go tissues at the ready catch u later Ali owl x
Posts.Title: Song for Jenny

Posts.Content: Me to Ali, off to bed now, swollen eyes in the morning from crying, again! X
Posts.Title: Song for Jenny

Posts.Content: yaaayyyýy finally done it !!!!! And it's still on,aalong with my ears, a bit dark though, I'm used to being half bald and grey, however, onwards and upwards my cyber buddies xx
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: I'm 'all shook up ' lol x
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Not bad alli, still very thin though, I think it will take a year to get it back x
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, sorry you had to join this gang, I was diagnosed last June, had mastectomy, chemo, rads and now on herceptin, I'm on the mend physically but mentally not great, I can identify with your feelings, I often have a feeling of unreality, it's difficult to put it in words to be honest, for me the mental aspect has been far worse than the treatment, I find if I keep busy it takes my mind off cancer for a while but I'm in danger of burning myself out because I'm doing to much, it's as if I won't stop so that I avoid thinking x
Posts.Title: New to all this!

Posts.Content: Hi morcambe, so sorry to hear your news, I can't advise you on secondary cancer but I know there are a couple of ladies here, who I'm sure will be along soon to help you. If it's any consolation there are many drugs, and combinations of drugs, that hopefully will be able to help you for a long time to come xx
Posts.Title: cancer spread

Posts.Content: Lol, I know x
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Yaaayyyýy well done Ali ,your brave to do it so soon after chemo, feels good doesn't it, back to some kind of normality, I'm off to the hospital in the morning for my 4th herceptin xx
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Cheers Ali xx
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Hi Rhonda, I've got much more sensitive skin now than I used to have before treatment, I had a terrible rash a few weeks ago on both arms, don't know what caused it but GP thinks it's the herceptin, but let's face it, with all the treatment we have had how can you pinpoint it x
Posts.Title: New Allergies

Posts.Content: Hi barb, I understand your fears for the future, we all have them, I'm not tnbc, I'm herceptin positive and estrogen positive, I think with tnbc you ladies are sort of put in a washing machine for roughly 8 months, then bang it ends, the likes of myself, after rads, we still have at least a year and 5 or 10 years of als, which maybe gives us a sense of reassurance that we are still being kept an eye on if that makes sense, however everyone has the fear of a reoccurrence, I think we have to learn ways of coping with these fears, there are some good courses out there available barb, I'm going on one called 'hope ' ran by mcmillans, but there are others, if you ask at your hospital they will give you the information. ultimately nobody's future is a certainty, cancer or not, there are many out there with various other ailments which have the potential to kill them, so you see barb at least we have been diagnosed and treat, some don't get that chance, I hope this helps a little barb, your not alone x
Posts.Title: Has treatment worked fears?!

Posts.Content: Lol, I used garner nutrieese in the end Al, it's a bit dark though, I now resemble ELVIS X
Posts.Title: hair dye the sequel

Posts.Content: Morning medusa, good luck with your first chemo, I wore the cold cap and it worked, I lost a bit on top and it thinned out, but,here I am with shoulder length hair, it's starting to grow on the top, it's about an inch long, I just tie it up and pile the lot on the top, it's quite grey so can't wait to dye it  (6 months). I would certainly recommend it x
Posts.Title: First chemo in a few days

Posts.Content: Thanks George and Jackie, do you know if herceptin lowers immune system also?
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Evening ladies and gents, can anyone tell me what the time frame is for a return of a normal immune system after chemo finishes?
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Thanks George and Jackie, yes I'm having the subcutaneous injections, had 2 up to now, odd sniffles at the moment xx
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Well done to your daughter rosalyn, one thing cancer as taught me, there are many, many good people out there, behind the scenes, who raise lots of money for charity x
Posts.Title: Race for Life

Posts.Content: Hi rob, sorry your feeling this way ,firstly, let's deal with the treatment, I don't how far down the road you are with this, yes it's difficult, it's long however it passes , don't push your family away, they  are involved regardless because they care, and don't be embarrassed about bc, in fact awareness needs to be raised for men with bc, I hope you have met mike, who's going through it and George who's been through it with his wife, and you have us rob anytime night or day, sometimes I've found the physiological aspect of this crap disease worse than treatment but this to will pass, take care rob x
Posts.Title: I can no longer cope

Posts.Content: Thanks variflow, I'm  the same, a bit paranoid now about germs and infections a hangover from chemo days methinks xx
Posts.Title: immune system

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie, I'm from the north east, I was diagnosed with bc last June, mine was invasive grade 2 with 1 lymph node involved, also herceptin positive so chemo was always on the cards for me, however, I had a mastectomy first then chemotherapy, my tumour was only 2cm, I wonder quite often, if  I had chemotherapy first it would have negated the need for a mastectomy, if yours was dcis you would not have needed chemotherapy anyway because your tumour was in situ, the only other explanation for radical surgery on dcis would be maybe the size or location of the tumour x
Posts.Title: Very confused tonight!

Posts.Content: Oh dear, you must be heartily fed up with hospitals x
Posts.Title: Here we go again.

Posts.Content: Hi pat, it's very tough when you're not feeling well and a little bit down, I used to feel like that pat especially when I was tired, I'm off for my first mammogram on Monday, I'm dreading waiting for the results, I'll be honest pat, even if they found anything I don't think I could go through another chemical cosh, keep your chin up pat, this to will pass as my mum used to say  x
Posts.Title: Hi there ladies.

Posts.Content: hi alli owl, I'm the same, I look as though I've been plugged into the national grid and my nails are crap, my hair also is growing very slowly, but, I bumped into a girl who used to work in my doctors, she had bc 5 years ago, she's ok now but her hair came back after chemotherapy then a few months later it fell out again, I felt awfully sorry for her, all she has are a few strands and the doctors think it's going to be permanent x
Posts.Title: neddys/moaning cows club !!!!

Posts.Content: Good news pat, keep up the chilling x

Posts.Content: Brilliant pics judith, he's adorable and Richard Gere ain't bad either lol xx

Posts.Content: hi Helen, just read your post, I was diagnosed last year with invasive ductal carcinoma, I had a mastectomy, problems with healing, followed by an unsuccessful axillary clearance  (long story) consequently chemo delayed by 2 months, finished treatment now and all is well, take that bike ride Helen xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed and need to read something positive

Posts.Content: Hi syers, I had ec chemo, finished now, on the very first cycle I got an infection and ended up in hospital for 4 days, when I was discharged I was given the injections to do at home for 7 days,  I did one, I felt absolutely lousy, I'll be honest, I stopped them, oncologist was a bit miffed about it, but the rest of chemo went by with no problem x

Posts.Content: Stick with it pixie, I used it, lost  a decent amount first round of chemo but it slowed down, I finished chemo in January and now still thinner, but no bald spots and shoulder length x

Posts.Content: Well done littlesusie, keep on smiling x

Posts.Content: Could be a side effect of the chemotherapy nettie, but I would contact you're bc nurse just to be on the safe side xx

Posts.Content: Hi bunners, I had the sub cut of herceptin, first one is a loading dose and felt a bit s##t for a day but after that plain sailing x

Posts.Content: Can't stop laughing weeble, you crack me up, I need talk, I haven't got the spots, but I've put 2 stone on, I've got a straggly bob with a tin tin tuft where my hair fell out, on a brighter note, my moustache has made a comeback ,and I've got one 38D and the other side is  a 38aaaaaaa xxxxx

Posts.Content: Well done you x

Posts.Content: I'm the same ladies, never had a ct or mri scan to this day and I've had a mastectomy, chemo, rads, herceptin and tamoxifen, the only scan I've ever had is for my heart for herceptin x
Posts.Title: How do you know if you have mets

Posts.Content: Hi bonbon, way to go, I'm with you on this one, I haven't got secondary cancer  (as far as I know ) but I can identify with the sense of urgency, I have the same instinct, and to tell you the truth, my instincts are usually right x
Posts.Title: lost a nail

Posts.Content: You will get there, I finished chemo in January with only one hiccup at the very beginning  (infection)      which was dealt with straight away, I don't know whether you have young children, I didn't, so I was able to rest,  it soon passes as well, drink lots of water try to eat well and a little bit of exercise and it will be over in the blink of an eye xx
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: You will get there, I finished chemo in January with only one hiccup at the very beginning  (infection)      which was dealt with straight away, I don't know whether you have young children, I didn't, so I was able to rest,  it soon passes as well, drink lots of water try to eat well and a little bit of exercise and it will be over in the blink of an eye xx
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Hallelujah, thanks everyone, yes I lose a conversation half way through, I forget what I'm doing, where I've put things, I thought it could be stress, but looks like I'm not alone, how long does it last, I finished chemo in January, it's quite frustrating at times x
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Thanks moomy, jump in anytime lol and Tony thank you x
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Anyone out there had it or got it, does it even exist?  If it doesn't then there's something going on with my memory, maybe I've lost the plot, that's if I ever had a plot lol x HELP
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your swift replys, I'm off to knock out a few zeds now I know I'm sane lol x
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hi fifi, I had ec chemotherapy also,  it's not as bad as the fec and t what most other women seem to have, in fact I don't think there are many ec only ladies on here, I've finished mine in January x
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC this Wednesday

Posts.Content: Good afternoon ladies and gents, hope you are all emotionally and physically as well as can be expected. I go walking every morning, does anyone know of any schemes for cancer patients ie classes, swimming or gyms that are subsidised, these activities are pretty expensive when you are off work with illness, any suggestions or advice would be gratefully accepted x
Posts.Title: exercise on prescription

Posts.Content: Course not Tony, the more the merrier x
Posts.Title: chemo fog

Posts.Content: Hi weeble, I've been on tamoxifen for about 3 months, the odd hot flush, no joint pain, I've had a little bit of down moments, but not sure if this is caused by tamoxifen or the situation x
Posts.Title: Good news!!

Posts.Content: Hi karan , what a bloody nightmare for you, I can't give you any advice other than what Helen as said, try and go walking to relieve the stress and deep breaths, I never know whether I'm coming or going if it's any consolation x
Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: Hi sheryl, looks like your sleep pattern is bad as well judging by the time you posted.  Yes I've said the same thing, wished I'd never knew. But if we never knew, we wouldn't have got treatment and what then?  At least now we have a chance to carry on and live, hopefully, long lives.  If we didn't get diagnosed it would have reared it's ugly head anyway sooner or later, and maybe then to late.  Everyone feels the same I think sheryl, I certainly felt and still do uncertainty for the future, I've just been on a six week course called HOPE, it's ran by mcmillan and I'm finding it usefull, it teaches you ways of relaxing and coping with anxieties about the future x
Posts.Title: Breast cancer recovery

Posts.Content: Hi sunnymo, I think the name of the course is 'take the wheel ' it's ran by mcmillan x

But if we never knew, we wouldn't have got treatment and what then?  At least now we have a chance to carry on and live, hopefully, long lives.  If we didn't get diagnosed it would have reared it's ugly head anyway sooner or later, and maybe then to late.  Everyone feels the same I think sheryl, I certainly felt and still do uncertainty for the future, I've just been on a six week course called HOPE, it's ran by mcmillan and I'm finding it usefull, it teaches you ways of relaxing and coping with anxieties about the future x

Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: Thanks shirls xx
Posts.Title: exercise on prescription

Posts.Content: Hi tilly, my chemotherapy finished in January and like you I wasn't to bad on it, I don't think your surgeon would operate while you're on chemo due to the risk of infection, so you would have to stop the chemotherapy, wait and then have your op, and yes, it would speed things up but you have come this far, I would plod on tilly with the chemotherapy, look at it as an insurance policy.  Good luck with whatever you decide tilly, but a word of caution, I wasn't to bad during chemo, but after rads and herceptin I now feel as though I've been trampled over by a herd of elephants x
Posts.Title: Can I speed up treatment

Posts.Content: Hi future,  I also take tamoxifen, I tolerated chemotherapy fairly well but tamoxifen I am struggling with. It's not so much the flushes with me, it's the fatigue, the weight gain, depression, lack of concentration and the list goes on,  I've been on multiple brands and they all seem to have the same effect, I'm seriously thinking, is it worth it?  I'm starting to think about packing them in if I'm honest, I'm fed up and I want my life back x
Posts.Title: Side effects from Tamoxifen after nearly a year

Posts.Content: Hi future,  I also take tamoxifen, I tolerated chemotherapy fairly well but tamoxifen I am struggling with. It's not so much the flushes with me, it's the fatigue, the weight gain, depression, lack of concentration and the list goes on,  I've been on multiple brands and they all seem to have the same effect, I'm seriously thinking, is it worth it?  I'm starting to think about packing them in if I'm honest, I'm fed up and I want my life back x
Posts.Title: Side effects from Tamoxifen after nearly a year

Posts.Content: Well done bev I was the same, had to phone them after 4 weeks x
Posts.Title: its official

Posts.Content: Good evening ladies and gentlemen, I'm starting to question my treatment for bc since I joined this site  (bit late now ). Most, not all, seem to have chemotherapy first to shrink their tumour which negates the need for mastectomy which seems like a good idea to me, however I had surgery first then chemo  (masectomy ). My lump was only 2 cm and at that time only knew i was estrogen positive. When my pathology report came back I was found to have multi focal tumours, 2 of them, both non invasive unlike the one that measured 2cm which was picked up via a mammogram, also 1 lymph node involvement and herceptin positive hence chemo, I'm not saying mastectomy was the wrong decision for me, in light of the 2 multi focal tumours, it was probably a good thing, however when the consultant advised a mastectomy he didn't know all this, so I'm left wondering why he made this decision on what he only knew at the time to be a 2cm, estrogen positive tumour.  Next concern is that everyone here seems to have had a different regimen of chemotherapy than me. I only had EC chemo and herceptin was not introduced until four weeks after treatment, unlike all you herceptin positive ladies who had yours towards the latter end of your FEC and TAX chemo.  Think I need George or misty on this one, so if either of you are out there in cyberspace please shed some light if you can, I'm a bit worried that my hospital have done things on the cheap and maybe they are of the mindset 'if in doubt chop it off ' sorry for this super long post x
Posts.Title: puzzled! !!

Posts.Content: Thanks George and misty, fingers crossed Ali for you, good luck with your results x
Posts.Title: puzzled! !!

Posts.Content: Hi susie, I also wore the cold cap and it was quite successful, it went a bit thin on top but I did a 'comb over', it's all back now as I finished chem in January, you will shed a good bit on your first chemo but don't panic and shave it off, I nearly did until a mate told me to see how it went, it still fell out a bit afterwards but slowed down, I'm so glad I waited, it's been worth the extra hours in the chemotherapy unit xx
Posts.Title: Cold Caps

Posts.Content: Well done monika xx
Posts.Title: No worrying features!

Posts.Content: Very handy that, George and Jackie, thanks x
Posts.Title: Indexed Terms and Abbreviations Dictionary For Everything BC Related...

Posts.Content: Lmao alli owl x
Posts.Title: stupid comments part 1!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi jj, sorry to hear your news, I had a mastectomy last July, for me it was the right decision as I was found to have multi focal tumours, where they are all behind the main one and didn't show on the mammogram, the main one was invasive, the other 2 were in situ, but if I'd only had a lumpectomy they would have missed the others, I'm glad in a way I had a mastectomy as I'm sure I would have been back under the knife at a later date. Hope everything goes smoothly for you jj, sometimes it's out of our hands and we have to place our trust in someone else's xx

Posts.Title: smoking! !

Posts.Content: I stopped smoking on Friday, Its took me some time to get my act together, I was to stressed to even contemplate stopping upon diagnosis, I wish I'd never started  (age 16 ). It's took my mind off bc though cause all I can think about is a ciggie, I dare not sit still for long, but I'm determined though, been given a fighting chance at life, sure ain't going to throw it away, any tips from ex smokers will be gratefully received,  or alternatively any smokers out there want to quit we can go through the agony together, it certainly ain't easy x
Posts.Title: smoking! !

Posts.Content: Thanks for all your support ladies and George, I'm gonna try the e cig today, I'm still off them and trying to keep busy, but I still really fancy one xx
